messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:54): oh yes SSID strings just gained meaning
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:55): http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/11/greater-choice-for-wireless-access.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:09): Using "ends with _nomap" as a flag doesn't sound the most highly scalable solution when someone else in the world invents a second SSID flag
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:13): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: they'll just have to accept that their flag might not be the last one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:13): I wonder what font rasterizer the Google Docs PDF reader uses
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:13): there's a maximum length of 32 characters
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:14): it's gonna be fun if there's more flags
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:14): the rasterizer manages to produce the kind of ugliness that's familiar to Windows users, but surely Google isn't running that stuff on Windows
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:14): is naming your SSID "_nomap" sufficient?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:15): what's the deal with people freaking out about SSID-based mapping anyway?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:15): what's the model of threat to privacy?
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:17): TabAtkins: okay if we publish your #fronteers11 video this week?

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:18): 8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083: btw, I occasionally see an old snapshot of http:/ 8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083hoetmer.nl/irc-logs/ in Opera Mini. Did you change caching headers? Did Opera make their caching over-aggressive? What has happened?
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:19): Old as in a day old?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:20): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: You might move to live in a secret new location to evade a stalker/criminal/etc, but would take your wireless router with you, and the stalker/etc could later query Google's access point database to figure out where you are now living
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:20): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: that cache is only updated once a day
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:21): 8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083: ok. it's annoying not to find the link to the latest log there from time to time
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:21): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: ok. that's a reasonable use case
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:22): Or you might carry an access point around with you (as an ad-hoc network or 3G-wifi-bridge thing) and people could discover where you had been in the past
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's a reasonable use case, too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:24): Or you might just be paranoid and hate Google
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:24): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it should update around 00:15 CET each day
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:25): Ah, I see, yeah, if there's no activity in a channel in those 15 minutes, the log isn't created yet
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:37): 8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083: can that be fixed easily?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:37): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you should bookmark /irc-logs/whatwg
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:37): it redirects to the latest
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:37): What edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e said

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I suppose. Back when I set up my Speed Dial, I expected to read #html-wg logs, too, but there's nothing interesting there typically
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:38): 8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083: it would be nice to have a link from the log page to the previous log, too
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (12:39): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, well, that only works if you stay up past midnight
8276c305beb1ebf1529fb8592cb24083 (12:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yeah, I should build that some day.. Even though the archive is static now

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:42): I updated my Speed Dial using a device with better bookmark management ergonomics. Let's see how long it takes for change to propagate to Opera Mini on the legacy phone
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:54): hello, I am trying to find or generate a stand-alone Javascript version of the HTML parser at validator.nu
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:54): tried GWT, but did not find any up-to-date pointers on the build process
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:55): ideally, I am looking for something less obscured than the GWT-generated one at livedom.validator.nu
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:55): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: http://www.davidflanagan.com/2011/10/html-parsing-wi.html
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: thanks!! reading..

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:57): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: you need to adapt the HtmlParser-compile-detailed script or the HtmlParser-compile-detailed.launch Eclipse launch setup to the path on your system and the details of your GWT version
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:58): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I did not see those in the tarball
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (12:59): oh- only found an old svn one so far
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:59): https://hg.mozilla.org/projects/htmlparser/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:00): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: where was the link to the old svn repo?
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:00): http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Validator.nu_parser
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:01): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: and thanks for the hg location! Did not find it at http://about.validator.nu/htmlparser/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: thanks. I fixed both pages
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:10): mattur's email archeology is awesome: https://twitter.com/#!/mattur/status/136411627695251456

82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:10): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it looks like David's parser might be better for my needs, but if I succeed in generating the JS through GWT I'll send you a script that is adapted to Debian
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:11): I feel that I now have to try the optimizations that David didn't try before he proceeded with a new implementation
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:11): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: RT'd that from @WHATWG :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): hmm

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): for styling anyway
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): yikes

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:18): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: but it does make sense

82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:26): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I get a lot of messages about annotations not resolving, like java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: nu.validator.htmlparser.annotation.Virtual
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:26): but it still seems to work
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:26): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: I don't know why the GWT compiler fails to find those
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:27): I am not of much help on Java or GWT unfortunately
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:30): I added a wildcard classpath (/usr/share/java/*) to make it work, not sure if that is considered good form
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:31): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: make it work in what sense?
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:32): to make it find the classes it needs
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:32): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: and the compilation result worked?
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:32): libcommons-collections3 and the gwt classes
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:32): will get you a link to pastebin in a moment
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:33): http://pastebin.com/rn1csAcq
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:33): there's supposed to be enough stuff under super/ to cover for JDK classes that aren't in GWT

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:34): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: ok. if you include /usr/share/java, distributing the compilation result might violate the license of your JDK impl. YMMV. IANAL.
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:35): can try to narrow it down
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:41): getting java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/tools/ant/types/ZipScanner
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (13:45): This works without wildcard on Debian unstable: http://pastebin.com/p6bMjmpP
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: hmm. that must be requirement for the GWT compiler itself
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (14:01): might be- I am not using the prescribed build setup for GWT, which might include additional paths. The gwt packages only list the jre as dependencies.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:04): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: I might goofed when I included GWT compiler input in -cp
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:04): might have goofed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:04): interesting developments around schema.org: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-data-tf/2011Nov/0117.html
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (14:09): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: if you mean the $APPDIR/* bits, then those seem to be needed
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (14:09): at least it fails to compile if I remove them
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:13): 82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9: there might be some other way to pass those to the compiler only so that the VM running the compiler doesn't see them
82cf689c6043e0122e61799d46705aa9 (14:14): ok, will let you know if I find something
